meanings.definition: To revert to the state as property that has no owner.
meanings.sent1: When someone passes away without leaving a will, their belongings may escheat to the government.
meanings.sent2: The abandoned house escheated to the city after years of neglect.
meanings.sent3: The lost toy escheated to the youngest sibling, much to their delight.
meanings.sent4: The forgotten treasure chest escheated to the sea, lost forever in its depths.
meanings.sent5: The unclaimed funds escheated to the state treasury, waiting to be claimed by rightful owners.

meanings.definition: The process by which property reverts to the state due to lack of heirs.
meanings.sent1: Escheating occurs when there are no relatives to inherit the estate.
meanings.sent2: The lawyer explained the concept of escheating to the confused family members.
meanings.sent3: The comedy movie had a hilarious scene about escheating a haunted mansion to the ghosts.
meanings.sent4: In the game of Monopoly, landing on an unowned property is like escheating it into your possession.
meanings.sent5: The history book detailed the various cases of escheating throughout the centuries.

meanings.definition: The act of taking possession of property that has escheated.
meanings.sent1: The official document confirmed the escheating of the abandoned land.
meanings.sent2: After the legal process, the city completed the escheating of the unclaimed assets.
meanings.sent3: The children played a game pretending to escheat the lost toys in the park.
meanings.sent4: The entrepreneur saw an opportunity in escheating neglected properties for redevelopment.
meanings.sent5: The museum curator oversaw the escheating of valuable artifacts left behind by unknown donors.
